David C. Graeber, Educator

What is a Culturally Responsive-Sustaining Education Framework?

Ensuring the engagement of all students is paramount to strengthening a school district. In order to meet students where they are and build critical thinkers who see the world through their own unique lens as we emerge from a global pandemic into a changing world, we must think about how to frame that experience.

May 8, 2022

Culturally Responsive-Sustaining (CR-S) Education Framework:

  • Grounded in four key principles:
    • Welcoming and Affirming Environment
      • Relationships with students and families
      • Collective responsibility to learn about student cultures and community
      • Materials that represent and affirm student identities (alongside the traditional cannon)
      • Socio-emotional tools
    • High Expectations and Rigorous Instruction
      • Student-led civic engagement
      • Project based learning
      • Student leadership opportunities
    • Inclusive Curriculum and Assessment
      • Current events incorporated into instruction
      • Student’s involved in curriculum planning process
      • Resources from racially, culturally and linguistically diverse perspectives
    • Ongoing Professional Learning
      • Learning more about the students in the seats
      • Support in aligning curriculum to fit new perspectives alongside other, more established voices.

Guidelines for culturally responsive sustaining education are grounded in a vision of an education system that creates:

  • Students who experience academic success
    • Are contributing members of an academically-rigorous, intellectually challenging school and classroom community
    • Demonstrate and ability to use critical reasoning
    • Take academic risks
    • Leverage a growth mind-set to learn from mistakes
  • Students who are socio-politically conscious (inclusive minded and asset focused) and socio-culturally responsive (mutual respect for qualities and experiences that are different from one’s own).
    • Acknowledge the limitations of their own perspectives
    • Empathy for others while appreciating differences
    • Demonstrate cooperation and teamwork, using active listening and communication skills to resolve conflict
    • Use interpersonal skills to build and maintain strong relationships, including those along lines of difference.
    • School environment (all layers – classroom, school, family, community) affirms and values the various aspects of students’ cultural identities (race, ethnicity, age, gender, sexual orientation, disability, religion, socio-economic background)
    • Recognize student strengths and offer opportunities for students to grow and learn
  • Students who have a critical lens through which they challenge inequitable systems of access, power and privilege.
    • Study historical and contemporary conditions of inequity and learn from historically marginalized voices

*A summary of the NYSED CRSE Framework: http://www.nysed.gov/common/nysed/files/programs/crs/culturally-responsive-sustaining-education-framework.pdf
